member.summary: Converts a collection into a string, where each element is separated with a comma, by default.
member.param: Collection to be converted.
Char separator. The defalt separator is comma.
Specify the surrounding chars for the elements. For example.: single quotation mark "'": 'element1','element2',...
member.returns: Returns a new string containing all the elements received, or null, if the source collection is null.

example.para: The following example shows how to convert a IEnumerable<int> into a string separated by commas.
The following example shows how to convert a List<string> into a string where each element is separated by a semi-colon and surrounded with sigle quotation marks.

member.name: T:Dlp.Framework.Container.IocFactory
member.summary: Dependency Injection Container.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Container.IocFactory.Register(Dlp.Framework.Container.IRegistration[])
member.summary: Register a component within the IocFactory.
member.param: The component to be registered. Create with the Component.For method.

example.para: The following example shows how to register an interface and get the registered component.
In this example, we register three types with the same interface. For cases like this, is a good practice to give a unique name for each type that implements the interface.
The implementation of the AcquirerFactory class could be something like the following:

remarks.para: When registering a type within an interface, if you do not specify the Name parameter, the type will be registered with System.Type.Fullname as the unique name. You can then reference any type by its fullname.

Also, keep in mind that when multiple types are associated with one interface and you do not specify the name of the type to be resolved in the IocFactory.Resolve method, the first registered type will be returned. In the above example, if we call the 'IocFactory.Resolve<IAcquirer>()' method, the container is going to return a new instance of the 'Stone' type.

example.para: Sometimes your architecture demands the use of the singleton pattern. By default, every call to the IocFactory.Resolve() method initializes a new instance of the requested type. You can define a type to be treated as singleton, with a single line of code, when registering the type. To do that, simply use the .AsSingleton() method after the implemented type that you want as a singleton.
In the following example, the

In many situations you may have to register multiples interfaces with its implementations, as for example, a set of repositories. As the next example illustrates, we have a namespace called Repository, containing several interfaces and its corresponding implementations. To register all the types from this namespace, you can proceed as follows:
example.remarks: If you need to register types from another assembly, as for example, the repository is in another project, simply use the Component.FromAssembly, specifying the assembly where the types interfaces to be registered are.

example.para: One of the advantages of most of the Dependency Injection Containers is the ability to intercept calls to any method of the registered interfaces. The IocFactory provides this funcionality in a easy way. The first thing is to create a class that implements the Dlp.Framework.Container.Interceptors.IInterceptor interface. This interface provides two methods, as shown in the following example.

Having the interceptor class created, you can define the interceptor to be used for every registered interface. The following example will result in every call to any method of the interface IAcquirer to be intercepted by the MyInterceptor class.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Container.IocFactory.Reset
member.summary: Clears all the registered data and interceptors.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Container.IocFactory.Resolve``1(System.Object[])
member.summary: Gets the class registered with the provided interface. If multiple types are associated with the interface, the first registered type is returned.
member.param: If the concrete class needs any parameter to be instantiated, specify them here.
member.returns: Returns an instance for the specified interface type.
member.exception: Either the specified interface is not registered or there aren't any concrete types associated with the interface.

example.para: The following example shows how to create an instance for a registered interface, using the IocFactory.Resolve method.
example.code: // Creates a new instance of the ConfigurationUtility type that implements the IConfigurationUtility interface. IConfigurationUtility configurationUtility = IocFactory.Resolve<IConfigurationUtility>();
example.remarks: The IocFactory.Resolve method always creates a new instance of the requested type. If you want to keep the same instance for every call, you must register the type as a singleton. Check the IocFactory.Register method to learn how to register types as singletons.

example.para: Sometimes the type to be instantiated needs some parameters in its constructor. The IocFactory.Resolve method allows you to pass parameters to the constructor of the type to be instantiated. The next example shows how to instantiate a repository that requires the connection string to be set in the constructor.

Another common situation occurs when a type needs another type as a constructor parameter. If both types are registered within the IocFactory container, this relationship is resolved automatically. The following example illustrates this scenario.

The above structure is a common pattern when working with repositories. Pay attention to the MerchantRepository class and note that it does not have a default constructor. It contains only a constructor that receives the IConfigurationUtility interface. The following example shows how to register and retrieves that repository.
example.remarks: Keep in mind that for this pattern to work, your class shall not contains the default constructor. If you class contains a default constructor, it is going to have preference when resolving the interface. If that is the case, you have to explicitly pass the instanced type as a constructor parameter for the IocFactory.Resolve method.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Container.IocFactory.ResolveByName``1(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Gets the class registered with the provided interface, by its name.
member.param: Unique name of the type to be returned.
If the concrete class needs any parameter to be instantiated, specify them here.
member.returns: Returns an instance for the specified interface type.
member.exception: Either the specified interface is not registered or there aren't any concrete types associated with the interface.

member.returns: Returns an instance of AssemblyInfo to be registered with the IocFactory.Register method.

member.summary: Load all the types from the specified namespace for the specified assembly, to be registered at the IocFactory.Register method.
member.param: Assembly containing the types to be registered.
Namespace containing the types to be registered.
member.returns: Returns an instance of AssemblyInfo to be registered with the IocFactory.Register method.

member.summary: Converts a DateTime object to the specified TimeZoneId. The converted date considers the Daylight Saving Time automatically.
member.param: DateTime object to be converted.
TimeZoneId for the current DateTime object.
Target TimeZoneId to witch the DateTime will be converted.
member.returns: Return a new DateTime object with the specified target TimeZoneId.
member.remarks: To get a list of all the available TimeZones, check the method.

example.para: The following example shows how to convert a DateTime object between different time zones.
The following example shows how to convert UTC DateTime to a specific time zone.
example.code: // Convert the UTC current DateTime to Brasília time zone. DateTime brasiliaDateTime = DateTime.UtcNow.ChangeTimeZone(TimeZoneInfo.Utc.Id, "E. South America Standard Time");

HTTP verb to be using when sending the data.
Content type of the transferred data.
Endpoint where the request will be sent to.

member.returns: Returns an WebResponse as a Task, containing the result of the request.

member.param: XML string to be deserialized.
Encoding to be used for deserialization. Default value: Encoding.UTF8.
member.returns: Return a new instance of type T with the deserialized data, or default(T), if the XML string is null.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Serializer.XmlDeserialize(System.Type,System.String,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Deserializes a XML string to an object instance.
member.param: Type of the instance to be returned.
XML string to be deserialized.
Encoding to be used for deserialization. Default value: Encoding.UTF8.
member.returns: Return a new instance of type T with the deserialized data, or default(T), if the XML string is null.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.Serializer.XmlSerialize(System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Serialize an object to a XML string.
member.param: Object to be converted.
Set to true to generate a indented XML string. Default: false.
Encoding to be used for serialization. Default value: Encoding.UTF8.
member.returns: Returns the serialized string, or null, if the source object was not suplied.

Encoding to be used for serialization. Default value: Encoding.UTF8.

member.name: T:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions
member.summary: String extension methods.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.GetBytes(System.String,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Converts a string to a byte array.
member.param: String to be converted.
Encoding to be used for conversion. Default value: Encoding.UTF8.
member.returns: Retorn a byte array generated from the source string, or null, if the string does not have data.

example.para: The following example shows how to convert a string to a byte array using the extension method.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.GetDigits(System.String)
member.summary: Get all the digits of the specified string.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return a new string containing only the extracted digits.

example.para: The following example shows how to extract only the digits of a zip code.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.GetLetters(System.String)
member.summary: Get all the letters of the specified string.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return a new string containing only the extracted letters.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.GetLettersOrDigits(System.String)
member.summary: Get all the letters and digits of the specified string.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return a new string containing only the extracted letters and digits.

example.para: The following example shows how to extract only the letters and digits of a string.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.Mask(System.String,Dlp.Framework.StringMaskFormat,System.Char)
member.summary: Masks the content of the specified string.
member.param: String to be masked.
Mask format to be used.
Mask character. Default character is asterisk '*'
member.returns: Return a new string with masked content.

example.para: The following example shows how to mask a credit card data using all the masks options.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.RemoveAccentuation(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces all the accented characters with its unaccented version.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return a new string without accented characters.
member.remarks: Only Latin characters are supported by this method. Use of unsuported characters will result in the interrogation mark to be used to replace the characters.

example.para: The following example shows how to remove the accentuated characters of a string.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.IsValidCpf(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the current string is a valid CPF.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return true if the string is a valid CPF.

example.para: The following example shows how to validate a CPF document number. The string can contain non digit characters.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.IsValidCnpj(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the current string is a valid CNPJ.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return true if the string is a valid CNPJ.

example.para: The following example shows how to validate a CNPJ document number. The string can contain non digit characters.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.IsValidEmailAddress(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if the current string has a valid email address format.
member.param: String to be checked.
member.returns: Return true if the string has a valid email address format.

example.para: The following example shows how to validate an email address format.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.AsCnpj(System.String)
member.summary: Formats a string as CNPJ (00.000.000/0001-00). If the value is not a valid CNPJ, returns the original string.

member.returns: Returns the string with CNPJ format.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.AsCpf(System.String)
member.summary: Formats a string as CPF (999.999.999-99). If the value is not a valid CPF, returns the original string.
member.param: String to be formatted.
member.returns: Returns the string with CPF format.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.AsPhoneNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Formats a string as phone number.
member.param: String to be formatted.
member.returns: Returns the string with phone number format.

member.name: M:Dlp.Framework.StringExtensions.AsZipCode(System.String)
member.summary: Formats a string as ZipCode. If the value is not a valid ZipCode, returns the original string.
member.param: String to be formatted.
member.returns: Returns the formated string as ZipCode.

member.name: T:Dlp.Framework.StringMaskFormat
member.summary: Enumerates all the available mask formats.

member.name: F:Dlp.Framework.StringMaskFormat.Password
member.summary: Masks all characters.

member.name: F:Dlp.Framework.StringMaskFormat.CreditCard
member.summary: Partially mask the string in a creditcard format, allowing only the last 4 digits to be seen. If the string length is less than 4, all the string is masked.

member.name: F:Dlp.Framework.StringMaskFormat.CreditCardExtended
member.summary: Partially mask the string in a creditcard format, allowing the first 6 digits and the last 4 digits to be seen. The string length must be greater than 13, otherwise the CreditCard format is applied.
